column1: Did President Obama save the auto industry? Even the most casual viewer of the Democratic convention would get the point: President Barack Obama saved the American auto industry. Massachusetts governor Deval Patrick called him the president "who saved the American auto industry from extinction." The former CEO of the super-sized used car dealership CarMax
column3: said the president’s decisive action to restructure General Motors and Chrysler "helped prevent a domino effect that would have taken down everything in the auto industry
column4: from the factories that manufactured auto parts to the dealers who sold the cars." And Michelle Obama talked about how her husband "fought to get the auto industry back on its feet." One should make allowances for the exuberance of political speech. But when a party shines a spotlight on a particular claim during the week when it trots out its best and brightest
column5: we should take a closer look. We ask
column6: did President Obama really save American auto makers? This is more a matter of opinion
column7: and not an item for the Truth-O-Meter
column8: but we can still shine some light on the question. In broad strokes
column10: but with some help from the other party and with one huge unknown -- no one can say what would have happened without massive government intervention. We spoke with a number of analysts and read many independent reports. There is no question that General Motors and Chrysler are profitable today. But so is Ford
column11: a company that received no financial aid at all. The jobs have returned -- although not nearly at the level they were before the industry began its steep decline in 2007. Without a doubt
column12: the American auto industry emerged smaller and more competitive. In the words of the bipartisan Congressional Oversight Panel that assessed the impact of the government's efforts: "The industry’s improved efficiency has allowed automakers to become more flexible and better able to meet changing consumer demands
column13: while still remaining profitable." Barack Obama
column15: cannot claim full credit for this outcome. According to several experts
column16: he needs to share it with his predecessor

column18: Rubenstein said. That allowed the Obama Administration to take a couple of months to assess the situation." Aaron Bragman

column36: the U.S. government now owns about 32 percent of the company. Private shareholders account for about 35 percent. The retiree trust fund owns about 10 percent. The union gave up the right to strike through 2015 and ended automatic pay raises. Back in 2007

column46: Mulally said, they could've taken the entire supply base into free-fall also
column47: and taken the U.S. from a recession into a depression." There is no guarantee that these gains are permanent. The auto industry is on firmer ground because it can sell far fewer cars than it once did and still be profitable. However

A key question for advocates of a conventional bankruptcy is whether private lenders would have come forward to finance any such deal. The view of most analysts is that the private money would not have been there. The Economist
column57: one of the bastions of free-market thinking
column58: came around to that view. Originally

column60: it offered an apology to President Obama. "Given the panic that gripped private purse-strings
column61: the magazine wrote in an editorial. It is more likely that GM would have been liquidated
column62: sending a cascade of destruction through the supply chain on which its rivals

The Economist concludes "by and large Mr Obama has not used his stakes in GM and Chrysler for political ends. On the contrary

column66: it is impossible to know if the American auto industry would have fared better without government money
column68: and without strong government intervention. Most likely

column71: the view among most analysts is that President Bush kept the carmakers afloat long enough for President Obama to put them on solid footing moving forward. If that matches the definition of a rescue
